head.title: Installing the &nice; compiler
head.keywords: nice, compiler, install, windows, debian, linux, unix

webpage.para: Select your system: Debian Unix Windows Other

listitem.para: install the package with dpkg -i nice_*.deb.

section.title: Unix
section.para:
Download the Nice.tar file and save it as /tmp/Nice.tar.
System installation (if you are root)
Uncompress the archive:
cd /usr tar xf /tmp/Nice.tar
User installation
Uncompress the archive in your home directory:
cd tar xf /tmp/Nice.tar
The &nice; tools are placed in the bin subdirectory. It is be a good idea to include it in your PATH.
That's it! &nice; automatically recognizes where it is installed.
If you use Emacs, you should also install the &nice; mode.

section.title: Windows
section.para: Download Nice.tar along with the nicec.bat file contributed by Jamie McCrindle. Further documentation is needed.
If you use Emacs, you should also install the &nice; mode.

section.title: Other
section.para: There are no specific instructions for other systems. Howevever &nice; can be used on any system that works with &java;. If you are in this situation, please contact me to share your experience and augment the documentation.

section.title: Emacs mode
section.para:
There is an Emacs mode for &nice; which makes Emacs the editor of choice for &nice; programs! To enable it, place this in your .emacs file:
;; Nice ;; Remove the ; in the next line if you installed Nice in your home directory ;(setq load-path (cons "~/share/emacs/site-lisp" load-path)) (setq auto-mode-alist (cons '("\\.nice$" . nice-mode) auto-mode-alist)) (autoload 'nice-mode "nice-mode" "Major mode for editing Nice programs." t)
The first line is there to ensure that the nice-mode.el file is in your Emacs load-path. You may also do that by moving the file to some standard directory. Or you may have to replace ~ by /usr or /usr/local depending on where you installed Nice.
The &nice; mode will then be loaded automatically when you open .nice files. Type C-h m for the documentation of the mode.
